abstract.text: An annotation view that displays a pin image on the map.

inlineContent.text: In iOS 16 and macOS 13 and later use an
to create a custom map annotation

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Return instances of this class from the

method of your map view delegate when you want to display a pin for one of your annotations. The pins displayed by this view are the same ones found in the Maps application. You can specify the type of pin you want to display and whether you want the pin to be animated into place.

In iOS 5.1 and earlier, the MapKit framework uses the Google Mobile Maps (GMM) service to provide map data. Use of specific classes of this framework (and their associated interfaces) is subject to the Google Mobile Maps terms of service, found at

abstract.text: Display map or satellite imagery within your app, call out points of interest, and determine placemark information for map coordinates.
The visual representation of one of your annotation objects.
An annotation that represents a map item
Returns the view associated with the specified annotation object.
An annotation view that displays a balloon-shaped marker at the designated location.
The supported colors for pin annotations.
An annotation view that displays a pin image on the map.
A Boolean value indicating whether the annotation view is animated onto the screen.
Returns the standard color for green pins.
The color of the pin head.
The color of the pin head.
Returns the standard color for purple pins.
Returns the standard color for red pins.
A string-based piece of location-specific data that you apply to a specific point on a map.
Annotate a map with location-specific data using default and customized annotation views and callouts.

doc://com.apple.mapkit/documentation/Map.title: Annotating a Map with Custom Data

abstract.text: Methods your app can implement to respond to layer-related events.
The complete list of properties and methods for accessible elements.
A role-based protocol that declares the minimum interface necessary to interact with an assistive app.
A set of methods that defines a way to add animation to an existing class with a minimum of API impact.
A set of methods for getting and setting the appearance attributes of a view.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A set of methods that the destination object (or recipient) of a dragged image must implement.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
A set of methods used to associate a unique identifier with objects in your user interface.
Methods that associate a unique identifier with elements in your user interface.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A collection of methods that gives you access to the appearance proxy for a class.
A protocol that a class must adopt to allow appearance customization using the [`UIAppearance`](doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIAppearance) API.
A set of methods for converting between different frames of reference on a screen.
A set of methods that can make a custom object eligible to participate in UIKit Dynamics.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
An object that can become focused.
The container responsible for providing geometric context to focus items within a given focus environment.
Methods that provide details about how to display your custom content in the large content viewer.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A type that can be an anchor for a popover presentation controller.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
A set of methods that makes the iOS interface environment available to your app.
The protocol you adopt to restore an objects state from a user activity.
A type that calls your code in reaction to changes in the trait environment.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
